importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe captures the immediate aftermath of the Gaza ceasefire deal, during which public opinion on Trump’s foreign policy and domestic economic performance is being evaluated.

keyTakeAways: Americans show little enthusiasm for Trump’s Gaza ceasefire deal, despite its international visibility.
Trump’s approval ratings remain at or below second-term lows, especially on domestic issues like the economy.
The AP-NORC and CNBC polls indicate that Americans disapprove of Trump’s handling of the Gaza situation and the economy at record levels.
Trump’s economic approval rating is at its worst in either his first or second term, with 62% disapproving of his inflation and cost-of-living policies.
Public confidence in the economy is at a new low, with only 32% expecting improvement in the economy and 31% expecting wage increases over the next year.
Americans are increasingly concerned about job security, with 52% of employed individuals now not at all worried about losing their jobs — a decline from previous years.
Foreign policy issues, including the Gaza deal, are low on Americans’ priority list — only 4% consider international events the most important issue facing the country.
A significant portion of Americans believe Trump has not prioritized lowering prices or addressing inflation, reinforcing the idea that domestic economic concerns dominate public sentiment.
The Gaza ceasefire deal, though hailed internationally, appears to have had minimal impact on Trump’s domestic popularity, highlighting the primacy of economic concerns in American public opinion.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Despite the announcement of a Gaza ceasefire deal, which was seen as a major foreign policy achievement, American public opinion has shown little enthusiasm for President Donald Trump’s handling of the situation. Polls from AP-NORC and CNBC reveal that Trump’s approval ratings remain at or below their lowest levels, especially on domestic economic issues, with 62% disapproving of his inflation and cost-of-living policies. The article argues that economic concerns, such as inflation, job insecurity, and stagnant wage growth, dominate public sentiment, overshadowing the international significance of the Gaza deal. Even though some believe the ceasefire could bolster Trump’s legitimacy or even earn him a Nobel Peace Prize, Americans prioritize economic stability over foreign policy outcomes. The article concludes that the true driver of public opinion is the economy — not international diplomacy — and that the Gaza deal, while notable globally, has had minimal impact on Trump’s domestic popularity.
title: Americans shrug at Trump’s Gaza deal, as economic fears reign
